so the question is how are we going to enable these new exciting applications well historically
uh in the past we had the answer and it was with device scaling we all know moore's law as we make
transistors smaller we can fit more in a chip but it wasn't really moore's law which dictated gains and performance
that was denard's scaling i think bob caldwell one of the chief architects of the pentium ships at intel really
said it best when he said that moore's law is what gives us more transistors but it's denard scaling which made these
transistors useful because denard scaling says that as i make my transistor smaller
i get gains in performance and the problem is that while we might be able to continue moore's law in the foreseeable
future to let's say 14 or 10 or seven or even five nanometer technology nodes the nerd scaling has long been broken
ever since the early 2000s so even if we can continue scaling devices
we are now seeing diminishing returns so if the question is well where's next i don't know 1000x
in computational power and efficiency going to come from uh it's unlikely that scaling alone is
going to get us all the way there so then what's the solution moving forward
well there's a device-centric approach right maybe there's a magic device out there which will solve all of our

but is giving us diminishing returns and there's certainly very important work looking at new types of physics
like tunnel fets instead of a mosfet which promised to be energy efficient

maybe it lies in architecture and again i do not believe that architectural solutions

they come at a high design cost and also have limited applicability because by definition they are

so if the solution isn't in just devices or just architecture what do we turn towards well i believe
the solution lies in nano systems which is when we can combine the benefits
of using new devices and new nano technologies with the benefits of new systems and new architectures
which are inherently enabled by using these new technologies
i think there are two very important aspects of nanosystems uh the first is uh being able to
transform a new device into a new system as an example carbon nanotubes
we know they make a pretty good transistor they have some unique fabrication processing they make great sensors for
more and more applications and the question is well what type of system or architecture do we want to

now the second important aspect of nanosystems is but once you think of the system you want to build you then need to build it

so while maybe you can build a single transistor or two transistors which are high performance building an

for you you see there's a squiggly one there and you see in this position c and t essentially creates erroneous
and random connections in a circuit causing incorrect logic functionality in fact here you see the pull up and polar
networks are no longer even complementary functions of one another a major no-no for cmos obviously
so that's missed position cnts what about metallic well a cnt is either semi-conducting or metallic
due to both the cnt's diameter and its chirality a semi-conducting cnt has a band gap of
around 1ev which is perfect for digital logic while a metallic cnt
has a band gap of around zero and thus uh it cannot be turned off by the gate it causes leakage current uh and can
also cause incorrect logic functionality and thus metallic c and t's are obviously additional major no-no's for a
circuit so how do we overcome these two imperfections well i'll start with mispositioned carbon nanotubes
and i'll start with a processing solution the processing solution is simple it's well let's just grow the c and t's
highly aligned and we can do this way for scale to do so we grow the cnts on a crystalline
quartz substrate and the cnts grow highly aligned along the crystalline plane of the quartz
we can achieve very high alignment roughly nine and a half percent so in this sem here the horizontal lines
are these catalyst stripes and these vertical lines are all the c and t's highly aligned which are running
horizontal on the wafer surface now while 99 and a half percent might
seem like a great number right and it makes sexy sems right i'm seeing some shaking heads

etch out a section of the circuit now this etch region which is defined within your standard cell
is absolutely essential as it guarantees that if there is any misposition c and t
which could have caused incorrect logic functionality part of that cnt must have gone through this etch region
and this would have been removed from the circuit now you might be wondering can you just draw these etch regions for a simple

and what i really want to highlight for you about misposition c and t immune design is that there is no per-unit
customization it these etch regions are defined with inner standard cells so you don't
inspect your wafer see where the misposition cnt is then make your design no the design works for any arbitrary

any logic you want of whatever size which is guaranteed to be 100 immune to any mispositioned carbon
nanotubes so now we can overcome this position c and t's what about metallic carbon
nanotubes well there is a trivial solution it simply don't grow any
and while this would certainly work it's currently unfortunately impossible and is an open challenge and

growth and for vlsi scale applications we need to remove over 99.99 of all
metallic cnts and previous attempts have really been inadequate
so the technique i'll show you today is called vmr which stands for vlsi metallic cnt removal now before i get
into the nitty gritty details of what vmr is i want to highlight that just like mispositioned cnt
mean design vmr is universally effective for all logic designs and also follows
vlsi design and processing flows so what is vmr well vmr is chip
scale electrical breakdown let me go through another concrete example for you here's the scm of a
real growth i've taken and just by looking at them i can't tell if it's a semi-conducting or metallic cnt no one
can so for this example i'll just assign them at random the first step of the process is to
deposit our vmr electrodes now these are interdigitated electrodes patterned at
my minimum lithographic pitch and as you'll see part of these vmr structures become
my final c and phet source and drain contacts now once i have this vmr structure on my
wafer i then perform electrical breakdown on this vmr structure
to do electrical breakdown we use the gates of the transistors to turn off the semiconducting cnts
you then apply a large bias between these two electrodes only the metallic c and t's can conduct
current because by virtue of b metallic they are not turned off by the gate and if you apply a large enough bias
enough current will flow through the metallic c and t's that they break down like a fuse due to a dual self-heating process you
can actually look under the sem and see the location of where the metallic cnts had broken down and been
removed from the circuit we basically fused them exactly it was exactly like a fuse exact same physics technology
so this doesn't leave debris lying around oh so this is yeah so an important part about this
is that these vmr electrodes that's a great question these vmr electrodes are patterned at the minimum lithographic
pitch and why is that important because if it wasn't then the remaining metallic segment of that cnt it could
still cause incorrect logic but because it's at the minimum pitch it cannot cause incorrect logic

so if i build a set of c and effects side by side i see that each c in fat will be

you need to have controlled cnt spacing variations now to characterize this non-uniform spacing

transfers the key to cider is a multiple transfer process
whereby we combine the cnts from multiple different growth substrates onto the same target substrate
